author: 237dmitry
body:
## Summary of the new feature/enhancement
Add ability to use environment variables in `using assembly` instruction. In case of loading from custom assembly location and in order to not writing full path.

## Proposed technical implementation details (optional)
For example:
```
using assembly $HOME\libs\taglib-sharp\taglib-sharp.dll
```

comments.author: SeeminglyScience
comments.body:
`using` is a parse time concept, so unless the variable is a true constant (which PowerShell doesn't really have) that wouldn't work very well.

You can however do *script* relative paths with `using assembly ./lib/something.dll`.  In a `using` statement that switches from current directory relative to script relative (confusing I know).

comments.author: vexx32
comments.body:
`using` statements are resolved before any code is actually executed, in most cases. PowerShell reads the script top to bottom and processes it, and it's during this step, before it actually runs any of the code, that these statements are processed and resolved.

As a result, variables don't have any actual value to read when trying to resolve those statements.

And yeah, Add-Type can do similar things but will still support variable usage and so on. 🙂
